dt: {bc}a broad band of cloth worn about the shoulders, around the neck, or over the head
{bc}a military or official sash usually indicative of rank

et: probably modification of Middle French dialect (Norman) {it}escreppe{/it}, Middle French {it}escherpe{/it} sash, sling, from Old French, pilgrim's shoulder bag, from Medieval Latin {it}scrippum{/it}
shortdef: a broad band of cloth worn about the shoulders, around the neck, or over the head
a military or official sash usually indicative of rank

dt: {bc}either of the chamfered or cutaway ends that fit together to form a scarf joint
{bc}an in-line joint made by chamfering, halving, or notching two pieces to correspond and lapping them

et: Middle English {it}skarf{/it}, probably from Old Norse {it}skarfr{/it} butt end of a plank
shortdef: either of the chamfered or cutaway ends that fit together to form a scarf joint
an in-line joint made by chamfering, halving, or notching two pieces to correspond and lapping them

dt: {bc}a scarf that has the form of a loop without ends and that is typically worn around the neck

dt.t: If you give me the choice between a traditional scarf and an {wi}infinity scarf{/wi}, I'll always choose the latter. No tying, no fringe, perfect length every time, and perfectly cozy for your neck—they're the perfect fall and winter accessory, and they're so easy to make on your own.

shortdef: a scarf that has the form of a loop without ends and that is typically worn around the neck
